natural problem:
Consider the line parameterized by
\begin{align*} 
x&= 4t + 2,\\ 
y& = t+2.
\end{align*}Find a vector $\begin{pmatrix}a \\ b \end{pmatrix}$ pointing from the origin to this line that is parallel to $\begin{pmatrix}2 \\1 \end{pmatrix}$.
natural solution: Here is a plot of the line: [asy] size(200);  import TrigMacros;  //Gives the maximum line that fits in the box. path maxLine(pair A, pair B, real xmin, real xmax, real ymin, real ymax)  {     pair[] endpoints = intersectionpoints(A+10(B-A) -- A-10(B-A), (xmin, ymin)--(xmin, ymax)--(xmax, ymax)--(xmax, ymin)--cycle);

if (endpoints.length >= 2) return endpoints[0]--endpoints[1];     else return nullpath;   } rr_cartesian_axes(-3, 9, -3, 6,complexplane=false,usegrid=true); pair A = (2, 2);  pair B = (6,3);  draw(maxLine(A, B, -3, 9, -3, 6));

We need a vector pointing from the origin to the line in the direction of $\begin{pmatrix}2\\1\end{pmatrix}$. That means that the tail of the vector will be at the origin, and the head of the vector will be somewhere on this blue line: [asy]

size(200);  import TrigMacros;  //Gives the maximum line that fits in the box. path maxLine(pair A, pair B, real xmin, real xmax, real ymin, real ymax)  {     pair[] endpoints = intersectionpoints(A+10(B-A) -- A-10(B-A), (xmin, ymin)--(xmin, ymax)--(xmax, ymax)--(xmax, ymin)--cycle);

if (endpoints.length >= 2) return endpoints[0]--endpoints[1];     else return nullpath;   } rr_cartesian_axes(-3,9,-3,6,complexplane=false,usegrid=true); pair A = (2, 2);  pair B = (6,3);  draw(maxLine(A, B, -3, 9, -3, 6));

draw(maxLine((0,0), B, -3, 9, -3, 6), blue);  [/asy] Since the head of the vector needs to be on the black line as well, it must be the intersection point of the two lines. The lines intersect when \[\begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \end{pmatrix} = k \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 2k \\ k \end{pmatrix}\]for some real number $k.$  In other words, $4t + 2 = 2k$ and $t + 2 = k.$  Solving, we find $t = 1$ and $k = 3.$  Therefore, the lines intersect at $\boxed{\begin{pmatrix}6\\3\end{pmatrix}}.$

[asy] size(200);  import TrigMacros;  //Gives the maximum line that fits in the box. path maxLine(pair A, pair B, real xmin, real xmax, real ymin, real ymax)  {     pair[] endpoints = intersectionpoints(A+10(B-A) -- A-10(B-A), (xmin, ymin)--(xmin, ymax)--(xmax, ymax)--(xmax, ymin)--cycle);

if (endpoints.length >= 2) return endpoints[0]--endpoints[1];     else return nullpath;   } rr_cartesian_axes(-3,9,-3,6,complexplane=false,usegrid=true); pair A = (2, 2);  pair B = (6,3);  draw(maxLine(A, B, -3, 9, -3, 6));

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b t :: real and v :: "real \<Rightarrow> real*real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> t. v t = (4 * t + 2, t + 2)"
and h1 : "v t = (a, b)"
and h2 : "a / 2 = b / 1"
shows  "a = 6 \<and> b = 3"
a_0.informal problem: Given a function $v(t) = (4t + 2, t + 2)$, find the values of $a$ and $b$ for which $v(t) = (a, b)$ and $a / 2 = b / 1$. The final answer is $a = 6$ and $b = 3$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes t :: real and x y a b :: real
assumes h0 : "x = 4 * t + 2"
and h1 : "y = t + 2"
and h2 : "\<forall> t. a = 2 * t"
and h3 : "\<forall> t. b = 1 * t"
shows  "a = 6 \<and> b = 3"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Consider the line parameterized by
\begin{align*} 
x&= 4t + 2,\\ 
y& = t+2.
\end{align*}Find a vector $\begin{pmatrix}a \\ b \end{pmatrix}$ pointing from the origin to this line that is parallel to $\begin{pmatrix}2 \\1 \end{pmatrix}$. The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix}6\\3\end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 Here is a plot of the line: [asy] size(200);  import TrigMacros;  //Gives the maximum line that fits in the box. path maxLine(pair A, pair B, real xmin, real xmax, real ymin, real ymax)  {     pair[] endpoints = intersectionpoints(A+10(B-A) -- A-10(B-A), (xmin, ymin)--(xmin, ymax)--(xmax, ymax)--(xmax, ymin)--cycle);
     if (endpoints.length >= 2) return endpoints[0]--endpoints[1];     else return nullpath;   } rr_cartesian_axes(-3, 9, -3, 6,complexplane=false,usegrid=true); pair A = (2, 2);  pair B = (6,3);  draw(maxLine(A, B, -3, 9, -3, 6)); 
 [/asy]
 We need a vector pointing from the origin to the line in the direction of $\begin{pmatrix}2\\1\end{pmatrix}$. That means that the tail of the vector will be at the origin, and the head of the vector will be somewhere on this blue line: [asy]
 size(200);  import TrigMacros;  //Gives the maximum line that fits in the box. path maxLine(pair A, pair B, real xmin, real xmax, real ymin, real ymax)  {     pair[] endpoints = intersectionpoints(A+10(B-A) -- A-10(B-A), (xmin, ymin)--(xmin, ymax)--(xmax, ymax)--(xmax, ymin)--cycle);
     if (endpoints.length >= 2) return endpoints[0]--endpoints[1];     else return nullpath;   } rr_cartesian_axes(-3,9,-3,6,complexplane=false,usegrid=true); pair A = (2, 2);  pair B = (6,3);  draw(maxLine(A, B, -3, 9, -3, 6)); 
 draw(maxLine((0,0), B, -3, 9, -3, 6), blue);  [/asy] Since the head of the vector needs to be on the black line as well, it must be the intersection point of the two lines. The lines intersect when \[\begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \end{pmatrix} = k \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 2k \\ k \end{pmatrix}\]for some real number $k.$  In other words, $4t + 2 = 2k$ and $t + 2 = k.$  Solving, we find $t = 1$ and $k = 3.$  Therefore, the lines intersect at $\boxed{\begin{pmatrix}6\\3\end{pmatrix}}.$
 [asy] size(200);  import TrigMacros;  //Gives the maximum line that fits in the box. path maxLine(pair A, pair B, real xmin, real xmax, real ymin, real ymax)  {     pair[] endpoints = intersectionpoints(A+10(B-A) -- A-10(B-A), (xmin, ymin)--(xmin, ymax)--(xmax, ymax)--(xmax, ymin)--cycle);
     if (endpoints.length >= 2) return endpoints[0]--endpoints[1];     else return nullpath;   } rr_cartesian_axes(-3,9,-3,6,complexplane=false,usegrid=true); pair A = (2, 2);  pair B = (6,3);  draw(maxLine(A, B, -3, 9, -3, 6)); 
 draw((0,0)--B, red, Arrow(size = 0.3cm));  [/asy]
 *)

theorem
fixes t :: real and x y a b :: real
assumes h0 : "x = 4 * t + 2"
and h1 : "y = t + 2"
and h2 : "\<forall> t. a = 2 * t"
and h3 : "\<forall> t. b = 1 * t"
shows  "a = 6 \<and> b = 3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: If $x = 4t + 2$ and $y = t + 2$ and $a = 2t$ and $b = t$, find the values of $a$ and $b$ that satisfy these equations. The final answer is $a = 6$ and $b = 3$.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes t a b :: real
assumes h0 : "t = a / 2"
and h1 : "b = a / 2"
and h2 : "a = 4 * t + 2"
and h3 : "b = t + 2"
shows  "a = 6 \<and> b = 3"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Consider the line parameterized by

y& = t+2.

     if (endpoints.length >= 2) return endpoints[0]--endpoints[1];     else return nullpath;   } rr_cartesian_axes(-3, 9, -3, 6,complexplane=false,usegrid=true); pair A = (2, 2);  pair B = (6,3);  draw(maxLine(A, B, -3, 9, -3, 6));

The lines intersect when \[\begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \end{pmatrix} = k \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 2k \\ k \end{pmatrix}\]for some real number $k.$  In other words, $4t + 2 = 2k$ and $t + 2 = k.$  Solving, we find $t = 1$ and $k = 3.$  Therefore, the lines intersect at $\boxed{\begin{pmatrix}6\\3\end{pmatrix}}.$
 [asy] size(200);  import TrigMacros;  //Gives the maximum line that fits in the box. path maxLine(pair A, pair B, real xmin, real xmax, real ymin, real ymax)  {     pair[] endpoints = intersectionpoints(A+10(B-A) -- A-10(B-A), (xmin, ymin)--(xmin, ymax)--(xmax, ymax)--(xmax, ymin)--cycle);
     if (endpoints.length >= 2) return endpoints[0]--endpoints[1];     else return nullpath;   } rr_cartesian_axes(-3,9,-3,6,complexplane=false,usegrid=true); pair A = (2, 2);  pair B = (6,3);  draw(maxLine(A, B, -3, 9, -3, 6)); 
 draw((0,0)--B, red, Arrow(size = 0.3cm));  [/asy]
 *)

theorem
fixes t a b :: real
assumes h0 : "t = a / 2"
and h1 : "b = a / 2"
and h2 : "a = 4 * t + 2"
and h3 : "b = t + 2"
shows  "a = 6 \<and> b = 3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Given that $a$ is equal to twice the sum of $t$ and $2$, $b$ is equal to the sum of $t$ and $2$, and both $t$ and $b$ are half of $a$, find the values of $a$ and $b$. The final answer is $a = 6$ and $b = 3$.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b x y t :: real
and V :: "real \<Rightarrow> real \<times> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> t. V t = (4 * t + 2, t + 2)"
and h1 : "\<forall> t. \<exists> a b. V t = (a * 2, b * 1)"
shows  "\<exists> a b. a = 6 \<and> b = 3"
a_3.informal problem: Given a function V(t) that maps to a pair of real numbers (4t + 2, t + 2) for any real number t, and given that for any real number t, there exist real numbers a and b such that V(t) equals the pair (2a, b), find real numbers a and b such that a equals 6 and b equals 3.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x y :: real and a b :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> t. a t = 4 * t + 2"
and h1 : "\<forall> t. b t = t + 2"
and h2 : "\<exists> t. (a t, b t) \<parallel> (2, 1)"
shows  "(a 1, b 1) = (6, 3)"
a_4.informal problem: Given two functions $a(t) = 4t + 2$ and $b(t) = t + 2$, find the values of $a(1)$ and $b(1)$ such that the vector $(a(t), b(t))$ is parallel to the vector $(2, 1)$. The final answer is $(a(1), b(1)) = (6,3)$.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes t a b :: real and vec :: "real \<Rightarrow> real*real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> t. vec t = (4 * t + 2, t + 2)"
and h1 : "\<forall> t. (a, b) = vec t"
shows  "a = 6 \<and> b = 3"
a_5.informal problem: Given a vector function defined as $\forall t. vec(t) = (4t + 2, t + 2)$, find the time $t$ such that the $x$-coordinate is $6$ and the $y$-coordinate is $3$.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes t a b :: real
assumes h0 : "\<forall>t. (4 * t + 2, t + 2) \<in> {(x, y). \<exists>a b. a * 2 = x \<and> b * 1 = y}"
and h1 : "(a, b) \<in> {(x, y). \<exists>t. x = 4 * t + 2 \<and> y = t + 2}"
shows  "a = 6 \<and> b = 3"
a_6.informal problem: Consider the set of all pairs of numbers $(x, y)$ such that there exist numbers $a$ and $b$ with $2a = x$ and $b = y$. Suppose that for every $t$, the pair $(4t + 2, t + 2)$ is in this set. If $(a, b)$ is also in this set for some $t$ where $x = 4t + 2$ and $y = t + 2$, show that $a = 6$ and $b = 3$.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes t a b :: real and x y :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and v :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> t. x t = 4 * t + 2"
and h1 : "\<forall> t. y t = t + 2"
and h2 : "\<forall> a b. v a = 2 * a"
and h3 : "\<forall> a b. v b = b"
and h4 : "v a = x t"
and h5 : "v b = y t"
shows  "a = 6" "b = 3"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Consider the line parameterized by
\begin{align*} 
x&= 4t + 2,\\ 
y& = t+2.
\end{align*}Find a vector $\begin{pmatrix}a \\ b \end{pmatrix}$ pointing from the origin to this line that is parallel to $\begin{pmatrix}2 \\1 \end{pmatrix}$. The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix}6\\3\end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 Here is a plot of the line: [asy] size(200);  import TrigMacros;  //Gives the maximum line that fits in the box. path maxLine(pair A, pair B, real xmin, real xmax, real ymin, real ymax)  {     pair[] endpoints = intersectionpoints(A+10(B-A) -- A-10(B-A), (xmin, ymin)--(xmin, ymax)--(xmax, ymax)--(xmax, ymin)--cycle);
     if (endpoints.length >= 2) return endpoints[0]--endpoints[1];     else return nullpath;   } rr_cartesian_axes(-3, 9, -3, 6,complexplane=false,usegrid=true); pair A = (2, 2);  pair B = (6,3);  draw(maxLine(A, B, -3, 9, -3, 6)); 
 [/asy]
 We need a vector pointing from the origin to the line in the direction of $\begin{pmatrix}2\\1\end{pmatrix}$. That means that the tail of the vector will be at the origin, and the head of the vector will be somewhere on this blue line: [asy]
 size(200);  import TrigMacros;  //Gives the maximum line that fits in the box. path maxLine(pair A, pair B, real xmin, real xmax, real ymin, real ymax)  {     pair[] endpoints = intersectionpoints(A+10(B-A) -- A-10(B-A), (xmin, ymin)--(xmin, ymax)--(xmax, ymax)--(xmax, ymin)--cycle);
     if (endpoints.length >= 2) return endpoints[0]--endpoints[1];     else return nullpath;   } rr_cartesian_axes(-3,9,-3,6,complexplane=false,usegrid=true); pair A = (2, 2);  pair B = (6,3);  draw(maxLine(A, B, -3, 9, -3, 6)); 
 draw(maxLine((0,0), B, -3, 9, -3, 6), blue);  [/asy] Since the head of the vector needs to be on the black line as well, it must be the intersection point of the two lines. The lines intersect when \[\begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \end{pmatrix} = k \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 2k \\ k \end{pmatrix}\]for some real number $k.$  In other words, $4t + 2 = 2k$ and $t + 2 = k.$  Solving, we find $t = 1$ and $k = 3.$  Therefore, the lines intersect at $\boxed{\begin{pmatrix}6\\3\end{pmatrix}}.$
 [asy] size(200);  import TrigMacros;  //Gives the maximum line that fits in the box. path maxLine(pair A, pair B, real xmin, real xmax, real ymin, real ymax)  {     pair[] endpoints = intersectionpoints(A+10(B-A) -- A-10(B-A), (xmin, ymin)--(xmin, ymax)--(xmax, ymax)--(xmax, ymin)--cycle);
     if (endpoints.length >= 2) return endpoints[0]--endpoints[1];     else return nullpath;   } rr_cartesian_axes(-3,9,-3,6,complexplane=false,usegrid=true); pair A = (2, 2);  pair B = (6,3);  draw(maxLine(A, B, -3, 9, -3, 6)); 
 draw((0,0)--B, red, Arrow(size = 0.3cm));  [/asy]
 *)

theorem
fixes t a b :: real and x y :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and v :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> t. x t = 4 * t + 2"
and h1 : "\<forall> t. y t = t + 2"
and h2 : "\<forall> a b. v a = 2 * a"
and h3 : "\<forall> a b. v b = b"
and h4 : "v a = x t"
and h5 : "v b = y t"
shows  "a = 6" "b = 3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Assume that $x(t) = 4t + 2$ and $y(t) = t + 2$. Also assume that $v(a) = 2a$ and $v(b) = b$, and that $v(a) = x(t)$ and $v(b) = y(t)$. Find the values of $a$ and $b$. The final answers are $a=6$ and $b=3$.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x y a b :: real and t :: real
assumes h0 : "x = 4 * t + 2"
and h1 : "y = t + 2"
and h2 : "vector [a, b] = vector [x, y] - vector [0, 0]"
and h3 : "vector [a, b] \<parallel> vector [2, 1]"
shows  "vector [a, b] = vector [6, 3]"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Consider the line parameterized by
\begin{align*} 
x&= 4t + 2,\\ 
y& = t+2.
\end{align*}Find a vector $\begin{pmatrix}a \\ b \end{pmatrix}$ pointing from the origin to this line that is parallel to $\begin{pmatrix}2 \\1 \end{pmatrix}$. The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix}6\\3\end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 Here is a plot of the line: [asy] size(200);  import TrigMacros;  //Gives the maximum line that fits in the box. path maxLine(pair A, pair B, real xmin, real xmax, real ymin, real ymax)  {     pair[] endpoints = intersectionpoints(A+10(B-A) -- A-10(B-A), (xmin, ymin)--(xmin, ymax)--(xmax, ymax)--(xmax, ymin)--cycle);
     if (endpoints.length >= 2) return endpoints[0]--endpoints[1];     else return nullpath;   } rr_cartesian_axes(-3, 9, -3, 6,complexplane=false,usegrid=true); pair A = (2, 2);  pair B = (6,3);  draw(maxLine(A, B, -3, 9, -3, 6)); 
 [/asy]
 We need a vector pointing from the origin to the line in the direction of $\begin{pmatrix}2\\1\end{pmatrix}$. That means that the tail of the vector will be at the origin, and the head of the vector will be somewhere on this blue line: [asy]
 size(200);  import TrigMacros;  //Gives the maximum line that fits in the box. path maxLine(pair A, pair B, real xmin, real xmax, real ymin, real ymax)  {     pair[] endpoints = intersectionpoints(A+10(B-A) -- A-10(B-A), (xmin, ymin)--(xmin, ymax)--(xmax, ymax)--(xmax, ymin)--cycle);
     if (endpoints.length >= 2) return endpoints[0]--endpoints[1];     else return nullpath;   } rr_cartesian_axes(-3,9,-3,6,complexplane=false,usegrid=true); pair A = (2, 2);  pair B = (6,3);  draw(maxLine(A, B, -3, 9, -3, 6)); 
 draw(maxLine((0,0), B, -3, 9, -3, 6), blue);  [/asy] Since the head of the vector needs to be on the black line as well, it must be the intersection point of the two lines. The lines intersect when \[\begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \end{pmatrix} = k \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 2k \\ k \end{pmatrix}\]for some real number $k.$  In other words, $4t + 2 = 2k$ and $t + 2 = k.$  Solving, we find $t = 1$ and $k = 3.$  Therefore, the lines intersect at $\boxed{\begin{pmatrix}6\\3\end{pmatrix}}.$
 [asy] size(200);  import TrigMacros;  //Gives the maximum line that fits in the box. path maxLine(pair A, pair B, real xmin, real xmax, real ymin, real ymax)  {     pair[] endpoints = intersectionpoints(A+10(B-A) -- A-10(B-A), (xmin, ymin)--(xmin, ymax)--(xmax, ymax)--(xmax, ymin)--cycle);
     if (endpoints.length >= 2) return endpoints[0]--endpoints[1];     else return nullpath;   } rr_cartesian_axes(-3,9,-3,6,complexplane=false,usegrid=true); pair A = (2, 2);  pair B = (6,3);  draw(maxLine(A, B, -3, 9, -3, 6)); 
 draw((0,0)--B, red, Arrow(size = 0.3cm));  [/asy]
 *)

theorem
fixes x y a b :: real and t :: real
assumes h0 : "x = 4 * t + 2"
and h1 : "y = t + 2"
and h2 : "vector [a, b] = vector [x, y] - vector [0, 0]"
and h3 : "vector [a, b] \<parallel> vector [2, 1]"
shows  "vector [a, b] = vector [6, 3]"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Given that $x = 4t + 2$ and $y = t + 2$, and that the vector $[a, b]$ is equivalent to the vector $[x, y] - [0, 0]$. If the vector $[a, b]$ is parallel to the vector $[2, 1]$, then prove that the vector $[a, b]$ is equal to $[6, 3]$.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes t a b :: real
and x :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
and y :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
and v :: "real \<Rightarrow> real*real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> t. x t = 4 * t + 2"
and h1 : "\<forall> t. y t = t + 2"
and h2 : "\<forall> t. v t = (x t, y t)"
and h3 : "\<exists> t. (a, b) = v t"
and h4 : "a / 2 = b / 1"
shows  "a = 6 \<and> b = 3"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Consider the line parameterized by
\begin{align*} 
x&= 4t + 2,\\ 
y& = t+2.
\end{align*}Find a vector $\begin{pmatrix}a \\ b \end{pmatrix}$ pointing from the origin to this line that is parallel to $\begin{pmatrix}2 \\1 \end{pmatrix}$. The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix}6\\3\end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof

     if (endpoints.length >= 2) return endpoints[0]--endpoints[1];     else return nullpath;   } rr_cartesian_axes(-3, 9, -3, 6,complexplane=false,usegrid=true); pair A = (2, 2);  pair B = (6,3);  draw(maxLine(A, B, -3, 9, -3, 6)); 
 [/asy]
 We need a vector pointing from the origin to the line in the direction of $\begin{pmatrix}2\\1\end{pmatrix}$. That means that the tail of the vector will be at the origin, and the head of the vector will be somewhere on this blue line: [asy]
 size(200);  import TrigMacros;  //Gives the maximum line that fits in the box. path maxLine(pair A, pair B, real xmin, real xmax, real ymin, real ymax)  {     pair[] endpoints = intersectionpoints(A+10(B-A) -- A-10(B-A), (xmin, ymin)--(xmin, ymax)--(xmax, ymax)--(xmax, ymin)--cycle);
     if (endpoints.length >= 2) return endpoints[0]--endpoints[1];     else return nullpath;   } rr_cartesian_axes(-3,9,-3,6,complexplane=false,usegrid=true); pair A = (2, 2);  pair B = (6,3);  draw(maxLine(A, B, -3, 9, -3, 6)); 
 draw(maxLine((0,0), B, -3, 9, -3, 6), blue);  [/asy] Since the head of the vector needs to be on the black line as well, it must be the intersection point of the two lines. The lines intersect when \[\begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \end{pmatrix} = k \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 2k \\ k \end{pmatrix}\]for some real number $k.$  In other words, $4t + 2 = 2k$ and $t + 2 = k.$  Solving, we find $t = 1$ and $k = 3.$  Therefore, the lines intersect at $\boxed{\begin{pmatrix}6\\3\end{pmatrix}}.$
 [asy] size(200);  import TrigMacros;  //Gives the maximum line that fits in the box. path maxLine(pair A, pair B, real xmin, real xmax, real ymin, real ymax)  {     pair[] endpoints = intersectionpoints(A+10(B-A) -- A-10(B-A), (xmin, ymin)--(xmin, ymax)--(xmax, ymax)--(xmax, ymin)--cycle);
     if (endpoints.length >= 2) return endpoints[0]--endpoints[1];     else return nullpath;   } rr_cartesian_axes(-3,9,-3,6,complexplane=false,usegrid=true); pair A = (2, 2);  pair B = (6,3);  draw(maxLine(A, B, -3, 9, -3, 6)); 
 draw((0,0)--B, red, Arrow(size = 0.3cm));  [/asy]
 *)

theorem
fixes t a b :: real
and x :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
and y :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
and v :: "real \<Rightarrow> real*real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> t. x t = 4 * t + 2"
and h1 : "\<forall> t. y t = t + 2"
and h2 : "\<forall> t. v t = (x t, y t)"
and h3 : "\<exists> t. (a, b) = v t"
and h4 : "a / 2 = b / 1"
shows  "a = 6 \<and> b = 3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Given two functions $x(t) = 4t + 2$ and $y(t) = t + 2$, and a function $v(t)$ that maps $t$ to the ordered pair $(x(t), y(t))$. Find a pair of real numbers $(a, b)$ such that $(a, b)$ can be obtained from some value of $t$ and $a/2 = b/1$. The final answer is $(a, b) = (6, 3)$.
